uk.ac.qmul.sbcs.evolution.convergence.handlers.documents

Class CodemlModel

  • java.lang.Object
    • uk.ac.qmul.sbcs.evolution.convergence.handlers.documents.CodemlModel

  • public class CodemlModel
extends java.lang.Object
    Representation of sitewise selection (dN/dS rates ratio) for codeml M0, M1a, M2a, M3, M4, M5, M6, M7, M8, branch-site and Clade models C & D.
    Includes methods to extract selected sites and do regressions on their indices to determine aggregation of selected sites for qulity-control analyses.
    Author:
    Joe Parker, Kitson Consulting / Queen Mary University of London
    See Also:
    CodemlParser, CodemlParserM1, CodemlParserM2, LinearRegression

      • getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilities

        public int[] getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilities()
                                         throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Iterates through the sites in the alignment to work out which may be under positive selection.
        Returns a list of indices of sites (indexed to 1, not 0!) which have greatest BEB support for last site class.

        Note that:

        • Sites with 0.333 < Pr(BEB(last cat)) < 0.5 will be counted, but may not have BEB products > 1;
        • The last site class is treated as the informative one, but some models (e.g. M1) this may not actually be under selection at all. It does not make sense calling this method on those models...
        • The subsets of sites picked up as 'selected' by this method may (for these reasons) differ substantially from those picked up by summing the (BEB * omega) products, as in getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilityProducts().
        • It therefore makes sense to call one or the other depending on what you intend to do with the data (and also verify the global omegas are sensible).

        Returns:
        selectedSiteIndices - int[] of site indices (indexed to 1, not 0!) for sites with highest BEB posterior for last site class)
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException
        See Also:
        calculateSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilityProducts(), getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilityProducts()

      • getSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilities

        public int[] getSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilities()
        Gets the intervals between selected sites - determined here as 'sites with last site class prob as majority.'
        Calls getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilities() to get this info.
        Returns:
        int[] of intervals (distances in AA/codons between selected sites.
        See Also:
        getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilities()

      • getSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilityProducts

        public int[] getSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilityProducts()
        Getter method for intervals of selected sites.
        Returns:
        - int[] of intervals of selected sites.
        See Also:
        calculateSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilityProducts(), doIntervalRegression()

      • getFilteredLastCatProbabilities

      • doIntervalRegression

        public void doIntervalRegression()
                          throws java.lang.Exception
        Do a regression of intervals (log-transformed, base e) Intervals are calculated between each codon with estimated w > 1 DOES NOT include first or last interval (from 5' to first w>1, or from last w>1 to 3') e.g. if omegas are (sites 1:4, 7:9, 11:19 and 21:24 omitted): 
         i      w
 5      1.5
 6      1.0
 7      1.1
 10     1.01
 20     1.2
 25     1.0
        Then the sites passing BEB would be: 
         i      w
 5      1.5
 7      1.1
 10     1.01
 20     1.2
        And the corresponding intervals assuming start/5' at 1 and end/3' at 25: 
         i      w       interval
 1      (5')    n/a
 5      1.5     n/a
 7      1.1     2
 10     1.01    3
 20     1.2     10
 25     (3')    n/a
        These are log-transformed (base e), sorted and regressed: 
         i      w       intrvl  log(i)  index
 1      (5')    n/a     n/a     n/a
 25     (3')    n/a     n/a     n/a
 5      1.5     n/a     n/a     n/a
 20     1.2     10      2.30    1
 10     1.01    3       1.10    2
 7      1.1     2       0.693   3
 
 > summary(lm_r)
 
 Call:
 lm(formula = y_vals ~ x_vals)
 
 Residuals:
       1       2       3 
  0.1322 -0.2643  0.1322 
 
 Coefficients:
             Estimate Std. Error t value Pr(>|t|)
 (Intercept)  -0.2427     0.4945  -0.491    0.710
 x_vals        0.8035     0.2289   3.510    0.177
 
 Residual standard error: 0.3237 on 1 degrees of freedom
 Multiple R-squared: 0.9249,    Adjusted R-squared: 0.8498 
 F-statistic: 12.32 on 1 and 1 DF,  p-value: 0.1767
        In this implementation this is done using LinearRegression, adapted from class of the same name, Copyright © 2000Ð2011, Robert Sedgewick and Kevin Wayne, Last updated: Wed Feb 9 09:20:16 EST 2011.

        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - - if there aren't enough intervals (<3) for a regression it won't do one...
        See Also:
        LinearRegression

      • getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilityProducts

        public int[] getSelectedSitesByBEBProbabilityProducts()
                                               throws java.lang.NullPointerException
        Iterates through the sites in the alignment to work out which may be under positive selection.
        Returns a list of indices of sites (indexed to 1, not 0!) with estimated omega > 1.
        Uses the PRODUCT of Pr(BEB(i))*(dN/dS(i)) for each i in available site categories
        Returns:
        selectedSiteIndices - int[] of site indices (indexed to 1, not 0!) for sites with estimated omega > 1
        Throws:
        java.lang.NullPointerException
        See Also:
        calculateSelectionIntervalsByBEBProbabilityProducts()

      • getIntervalsRegression

        public LinearRegression getIntervalsRegression()
                                        throws java.lang.Exception
        Getter method for the regression of log-transformed selected sites intervals
        Returns:
        LinearRegression of indices against log-transformed selection intervals
        Throws:
        java.lang.Exception - - if there are too few intervals for a regression it won't do one
